description.en: These diverse disciplines draw from semiotics, philosophy, mathematics and physics. For example, the "positive sympathies" in Peirce's agapistic evolution will be offered as a source of novel dynamics able to resolve intrinsic tensions in semiosis. The "novel dimensions" in Gilbert Simondon's theory of Individuation will similarly characterize this radical creativity. The radical emergence of mathematician Giuseppe Longo will help characterize this generativity more formally, while various physical concepts - such as entropy and work - will also ground Peirce's agapism, Simondon's novel dimensions and Longo's radical emergence.
description.et: Kursus ammutab eri valdkondadest, nagu semiootika, filosoofia, matemaatika ja füüsika. Näiteks Peirce'i agapistliku evolutsiooni "positiivsed sümpaatiad" käiakse välja uute dünaamikate allikatena, mis on võimelised semioosi olemuslikke pingeid lahendama. Gilbert Simondoni individuatsiooni-teooria "uudsed dimensioonid" iseloomustavad sarnaselt radikaalset loovust. Matemaatik Giuseppe Longo radikaalne emergents aitab seda generatiivsust formaalsemalt iseloomustada, sellal kui eri mõisted füüsikast, nagu entroopia ja töö, põhistavad Peirce'i agapismi, Simondoni uudsed dimensioonid ja Longo radikaalse emergentsi.

objectives.en: The main objective is to understand semiosis via radical creativity. A core premise of this course is that semiosis, as adaptive meaning-making, must continuously problematize itself via a continuously embodied tension. This requires that novel dynamics be commensurately generated to resolve these intrinsic tensions. Assuming this, the question arises: from whence do these novel dynamics emerge? This course will endeavor to provide the student with numerous answers to this question from diverse perspectives.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärgiks on mõista semioosi lähtuvalt radikaalsest loovusest. Kursuse põhieelduseks on, et semioos kui adaptiivne tähendusloome peab iseend pidevalt problematiseerima katkematult kehastunud pinge teel. See nõuab, et vastavalt tuleb luua uudseid dünaamikaid nende olemuslike pingete lahendamiseks. Seda eeldades tekib küsimus: millest need uued dünaamikad tekivad? Käesolev kursus pakub tudengeile eri perspektiividest hulga vastuseid sellele küsimusele.

learning_outcomes.en: There are two main outcomes: 1) understanding the core premise that semiosis is an embodied tension that must somehow continuously resolve itself, and 2) provide different perspectives by which this understanding can be argued for/against, along with answers to how such self-resolving tensions exist in the semiosic body. Both outcomes involve exploring diverse disciplines that bare upon this dynamical process of semiosis and its intrinsically generative nature.
learning_outcomes.et: Kursusel on kaks peamist õpiväljundit: 1) mõista põhieeldust, et semioos on kehastunud pinge, mis peab iseend pidevalt mingil moel lahendama, ja 2) pakkuda eri perspektiive, mille abil saab sellele arusaamale poolt ja vastu argumenteerida, koos vastustega sellele, kuidas niisugused iselahenevad pinged eksisteerivad semioosilises kehas. Mõlemad õpiväljundid seisnevad eri valdkondade uurimises, mis puutuvad sellesse dünaamilisse semioosiprotsessi ja tema loomuldasa generatiivsesse loomusse.

independent_work.et:
Homework will consist of one or two questions posed after each lecture. Moodle will be used to collect answers to these questions between courses.

Readings and/or videos, comprised of selections totaling less than 6 pages and 45 minutes of video per week, will also be assigned via Moodle in preparation for each lecture.

Presentations, as scheduled, will be required from each student; depending on class size, student groups of 2-3 may be required. These presentations will endeavor to characterize the creative nature of semiosis through two perspectives that may be from the lectures or of the students' choosing.

Papers, due by (date?), will be required from each student individually. These papers will be between 4000 and 6000 words; they will characterize the creative nature of semiosis through three distinct perspectives. These may be an extension of their presentation.

grade_preconditions.et:
To Receive a 'Pass' Assessment:

Homework Assignments:  There will be readings and/or videos that will be assigned each week, unless otherwise noted.  These readings/videos will have a few questions that are to be answered by the lecture after the assignment has been posted.  One homework may be missed without penalty or explanation.  Beyond that, missed assignments must be negotiated with the instructor.

Additionally, both a presentation and a paper will be required to pass the course.

description.et: Course Overview and "how to write a paper".

topic.et: Dr. Who's Tardis: The Infinite vs. the Transfinite

description.et: This lecture and subsequent discussion will illustrate different types of infinity and how they are a precondition for veritable semiosis.  How are transfinite potentials possible in finite actuals?  Select readings on Peirce's Synechism, Simondon's metastable pre-individual charge and Cantor's transfinite will be discussed.

In contrast to the transfinite phenomena in the previous lectures, this lecture will review the history of cybernetics over the last century, leading up to today's so-called "AI" and to the implicit theoretical frames that limit our understanding of meaning-making in biological systems.

topic.et: Infinite Regress: The Epistemic Cut in Practice

description.et: Building off legacy cybernetic frames outlined previously, this course further explains how the problem of the epistemic cut, characterized by Prigogine and then Hoffmeyer, precludes a semiosic understanding of self.

topic.et: Irreducibility: Static Signs versus Processual Semiosis

description.et: This lecture, building off the tension intrinsic to transfinite phenomena, will characterize irreducibility via the metaphysics of Actuality, Virtuality and Habituality in the work of Duns Scotus, Peirce, Lotman, Simondon, Hoffmeyer and Deleuze.

This lecture, framed by the metaphysics in the previous lecture, will ground semiosis in some of the following phenomena: physical dynamics of potential and kinetic energy; the emergence of novel dynamics, or "dimensions", as in the work of G. Longo; thresholds in critical systems; entropy; indeterminate chaos; Simondon's physical vs. vital individuation; and work.

topic.et: A Science of Synechism I: Dodging Epistemic Dead-ends via Deliberate Invention

description.et: This course will employ the transfinite potential discussed earlier to outline a viable semiosic self, a characterization that transcends the epistemic cut and cybernetic modes of being.  This lecture will illustrate this more viable mode of becoming through artistic and architectural modes of creation, from practices of conceptual blending to the systematic creating of complex, while singular, solutions to arbitrarily complex problems.

topic.et: A Science of Synechism II: Dodging Ontic Dead-ends via Intrinsic Invention

description.et: This course will address the question begged by the previous lecture: how can deliberate human creation be understood to exist in biology intrinsically?  A model of semiogenesis will be summarized to explain how this intrinsic evolutionary capacity - understood by Peirce as agapastic evolution - is possible.
